ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Steph Carlisle
steph carlisle
Stephanie Carlisle
Steph Carlisle
Stephanie
Stephanie Carlisle
Stephanie Carlisle

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: My main main concern is that the professor (transparently) favors architecture students over FES students. To the extent that forestry students are in the class to inform architecture practice and the architecture students rather than the other way around -- or an equal balance. This was a hard pill to swallow sometimes.

Discussion-based classes often suffer from a lack of direction, which I think this class did to some extent. Still, the content was interesting and the professor did a good job of navigating through different ideas from the students.
the subject matter presented in this course is extremely interesting.
The project was good. I wish it had been a larger part of the course. Also, the discussions were enlightening.
Readings (some), final project.

The opportunity to view the process of design from the perspective of architects. It is clear that there are differences in priorities that make the implementation of ecological design difficult. The class provided an opportunity to not only discuss those differences but experience them as well as architects and forestry students worked together.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: the professor, it seems, has too much on his plate. Simply, if given more attention the course would be more successful

The instructor needs to be more organized and better at managing time so that class does not overrun the allotted time and that we can accomplish what is intended. He also needs to speak a bit more slowly.

Deliverables need to be clearly outlined early on. We never knew what we were presenting when, or how long it should be. It's hard to be motivated to work on the project when your projects in every other class are very well defined in terms of deliverables and deadlines. I was more likely to put this class off for last because the instructor always sent out assignments last minute, so it seemed like he wanted the work to be last-minute. My schedule is extremely full. It is difficult for me to make last minute plans during the semester. So when I receive an assignment one or two days beforehand, I just can't fit it into my schedule. In this case, we even had an assignment sent out ON Thanksgiving. That was frustrating.The mini projects we did seemed shallow. I would have liked to spend more time on the final project and gone deeper with it.
Felson can be hard to track down for meetings and help with assignments. Some of the readings were not helpful.

The overall organization was lacking and made it difficult to get feedback as the course progressed. The absence of time management during the 3 hour class sessions caused the need for many meetings outside of class which were very difficult to schedule between architects, forestry students, and Professor Felson. I think it would be beneficial for the class to be split into separate meetings of lecture and 'reviews' or even a regular time for office hours so that there is a more structured schedule. I also think that there is some obligation on the part of the professor to include a syllabus that will be followed throughout the course from the beginning of the semester. The emails sent each week, only a few days before class with expectations for that week's session did not provide any opportunity to plan ahead and manage one's time in order to give the class a good effort on a weekly basis.
Clarity on expectations. Providing assignments and readings with enough advance notice (more than a day or 2 before the next class).

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: the instructor did meet with students but at "show up" rate of only 60-70%
Good. The instructor's insight and guidance was extremely helpful. We often got stuck. But after 5 minutes of conversation with Alex, everything made sense again.
Great.

Professor Felson was extremely busy and often moved meetings repeatedly. Considering the amount of investment he has in student projects (which was great) the entire class would run more smoothly if he set out regularly scheduled times for non-class meetings. In general I was frustrated by how difficult it was to schedule between architects and forestry students and the unreliability of professor Felson exacerbated the problem.
While available and willing to help, offering his many great ideas added to our confusion and made it more difficult to focus and develop a particular idea.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: the course provides a link of ecology and design

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to think about design and how to incorporate research into design.
I'm interested in sustainable design. I didn't really have any options other than this class.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
No.

From the course description I wasn't completely aware of the extent that 'ecological urbanism' is related to experimentation. While it was interesting to learn about, I was not expecting it to have that emphasis.
No. It stayed at the level of "things to think about." I'm not confident that the final project resulted in an example of Ecological Urbanism in application/practice.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
I was delighted with the opportunity to work on a specific site in a studio-like setting with reviews. It was a great preview for what it is like to be involved in the design professions.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Hard to schedule meetings, especially across schools. Also, the architecture students seemed less dedicated and interested in learning about the other side of the process.
I had a great group. I only wish that we had to have more deliverables along the way for one project rather than multiple projects.

The group work was key. It would have been better if there were more architects in the class. But it was better to work in groups of 3 than to have some groups be without an architecture student. That would have been awful.
Great bringing architects and FES students together.

I felt that the architects did not have as much interest in the course and that it was often pushed to the bottom of their priority list in place of their studio work. I also felt that, especially at the end of the semester, the forestry students were asked to sympathize unfairly with the 'busy architects'. We all have a lot of work, especially at the end of the semester, and I don't think the architecture students should be asked to pull any less weight in the class than the forestry students.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start thinking about a project from day one. Start researching your ideas on day two. Your project will change a lot. You won't get as much time to work on your project as you want, so it's important to get a head start.
Know your scientific method. Develop your idea early on and seek to refine it.
